title: Chapter 7. Is it EVER possible to file motion to Avoid a Lien against an HOA lien against home. They sued me. I want 2 keep home
question: They sued me for back HOA and stuck a bunch of atty fees etc. on there. I want to keep the house. I know I would have to pay from here on out. They filed an abstract of judgment after a lawsuit and filed an abstract against my home.
answers:
California law does not seem to require a lawsuit before an HOA may record a notice of delinquent assessment and place a lien on the property. If the statutory route was followed, then the lien is probably unavoidable under 11 U.S.C. 545, because by being recorded it is already perfected against a bona purchaser. In that case, it would appear that the HOA could foreclose its lien after the bankruptcy is over, even though it can never ask you to pay the dues (because your personal liability is discharged in the bankruptcy). If that's the case, then you might consider converting to chapter 13 and paying off (or stripping off) the judgment lien over the life of the plan.

However, if the HOA did sue as you indicate above and the judgment lien was recorded, then the judgment lien is avoidable under 11 U.S.C. 522(f) as long it impairs your homestead exemption. Some people mistakenly believe that you cannot avoid a lien if you have no equity (and therefore no interest to exempt) in your home. But that's not true. Your exemption is impaired to the extent that all liens, plus your available homestead exemption (whether used or not) exceed the fair market value of the home. Again, if you wish to explore this option, you would do best to consult an experienced bankruptcy attorney in your area.

Good luck!

Consult with an attorney in whom you have confidence. There are several ways of avoiding liens, but the outcome will vary based upon several factors and facts, such as whether the lien arises by statute or by judgment, by when the lien was obtained, by what Chapter of the Bankruptcy Code you file your case, and by what is permitted in the jurisdiction in which your Bankruptcy Court is located. For example:
11 U.S.C. Sec. 547 -- preferential transfer: would permit avoidance/cancellation of a lien -- judicial or statutory -- obtained within less than or on 90 days prior to the date on which your bankruptcy case is filed, regardless of which Chapter (but in Chapter 7 the right to bring this action belongs initially to the Chapter 7 trustee. If the trustee declines to initiate the action, you could then file it under 11 U.S.C. Secs. 522(g) and (h).
11 U.S.C. Sec. 522(f) -- impairment of an exemption: would permit avoidance/cancellation of a judicial lien to the extent it impairs a claimed (or allowed to be claimed) exemption (but this Section pertains only to a lien arising by a judgment, and generally an HOA lien is a statutory lien which arises by statute),
11 U.S.C. Sec. 506(a) and (d) -- determination of extent of the lien: would permit avoidance/ cancellation of a statutory or a judicial lien if the value of the property is less than the amount(s) owed on liens which already existed at the time the HOA obtained its lien (so if the real property had a value of $100,000.00 but the mortgage balance was $105,000..00 then there would not be any equity to which the HOA lien would attach, and the lien could be avoided and the debt treated as unsecured) -- but generally this is not permitted in Chapter 7 (Supreme Court's Dewsnup v. Timm) and is allowed only in a Chapter 11 or Chapter 13 case.

The lien might be dischargeable as you state that the HOA sued you. Thus, it seems as if the lien would be considered a "judicial lien." You have little to lose if this is the case in that if the court doesn't agree with you, unlikely that you would have to pay the other sides' attorney fees. Perhaps you could file the motion, and then negotiate w/ the HOA to remove their lien.
Bottom line, you should retain an experienced attorney to assist you with your BK as paying off creditors prior to filing BK can create other issues.

You can always file a motion, you just can't win in this situation. HOA dues create a statutory lien, and avoiding a lien in Chapter 7 allows someone to avoid a judicial lien.

Another option might be to file a Chapter 13 & object to the proof of claim filed by the HOA. The Chapter 13 Court could then rule on the value of the claim & determine if the fees were reasonable.

Hope this perspective helps!

Judgment liens may be avoided under 11 USC 522(f); however, an HOA lien might arise under a land covenant and not be avoidable.

Consult a local attorney.
